_scenario.name: The Hypocrisy Spike
_scenario.description: A system with apparently good raw metrics but a dissonance level near the Δ(Σ) maximum zone. Demonstrates how moderate Σ can be more dangerous than extreme Σ because it is harder to detect.
_scenario.key_insight: Δ(Σ) = Σ/(1+Σ)² peaks near Σ ≈ 1.0. This system sits at Σ = 0.95 — maximum hypocrisy damage with minimum visibility.
_scenario.author: Rafa — The Architect

psi_hard.note: Despite decent individual metrics, Σ crushes Ψ below critical

psi_soft.note: The soft metric shows moderate resilience — the damage is in the hard penalty

delta_sigma.note: Almost exactly at the theoretical maximum (0.2500 at Σ=1.0). This is the maximum-damage zone.

xi_efficiency.note: Efficiency is fine — this is not a capability problem

plenitude.note: Near zero — epistemic humility has collapsed under dissonance pressure

expected_results.key_observation: This scenario is particularly insidious because individual parameters (P=0.78, α=0.72, Ω=0.85, I=0.90) all look reasonable. A traditional benchmark-based evaluation would rate this system as 'good'. Only the Ψ formula reveals the hidden collapse caused by Σ sitting in the maximum-damage zone.

expected_paths.note: Only Plenitude path triggers because Σ=0.95 is just below the PATH-Σ threshold of 1.0. This is a design limitation acknowledged in LIMITATIONS.md — the threshold may need adjustment.

lessons: Moderate dissonance (Σ ~ 1.0) is more dangerous than extreme dissonance (Σ > 2.0) because Δ(Σ) is at its maximum
Individual metrics can look healthy while the composite Ψ is collapsed
The hard penalty (k=2) is essential — the soft metric (k=1) would classify this as merely degraded
Plenitude and Ψ are the most sensitive detectors for this failure mode
